history.content: Legit question, but honestly don't think EECS Piazza is the right place for this.

children.subject: In that case, is there any faculty that can comment on the validity of this concern?
I’m just curious, what class is this?

I don’t know if this is actually a campus *policy* or a mere convention. The only source I managed to find on the matter listed it as a convention. So, there might be nothing you can do. 

But that being said, if I were in your place, I would email the Chair of the department explaining the situation in a calm and composed fashion, and request that something be done about it. Again, I don’t think this a policy so tread carefully.
By the way, it is totally possible that the professor is unaware of the Berkeley time due to first-time teaching. So in that case, reporting also resolves the issue.
Though there seems to be no policy about Berkeley time, I think it is worth a reporting. Teachers are hired to teach students. Proper accommodations must be made.

history.content:
The professor of a class I am taking insists on starting class on the hour, instead of at Berkeley time.

I have a class that ends right before this humanities class. It is physically impossible for me to be at this class any earlier than 10 after the hour, which is standard Berkeley time. Both classes are required for me to graduate. So I can’t drop either. I am also not the only student that is unable to arrive on the hour.

This seems like an issue. Adherence to Berkeley Time allows all students to arrive more or less on time, regardless of if the student has a class before or not. I feel like I am at a severe disadvantage to miss 1/6 of the material every class because of this.

This seems doubly wrong because the “on the hour” start time was not communicated to anyone until the first class. I would have chosen a different class had I known this.

my question is, is this reportable? Can I report this as an issue to the university or the professor’s department? Would anything be done about it? It’s just plain unfair that 20% of the class has to play catch-up without knowing what we got ourselves into.
history.subject: Violating Berkeley Time
